properties.summary:
"Human-induced climate change has contributed to an increased frequency and intensity of short-term heat waves and
heat stress, over central and eastern Europe though quantitative estimates of how much change has occurred in the likelihood of the 2015 event are highly uncertain depending on the methodology used."

"Modeling experiments indicate that human-induced climate
change was a major factor in setting the conditions for the development of 2015 European heat waves."

"The probability of recording breaking heat over Northwest
China in July 2015 was made three-fold more likely due to human-induced climate change."

"Extreme daytime maximum temperatures like those observed
in western China in July 2015 were made at least three times
likely by climate change."

"The Japanese heat wave of early August of 2015 was mainly
due to a naturally occurring weather pattern, however, anthropogenic warming increased the probability of occurrence of the event by 1.5 to 1.7 times."

"Climate change may have exacerbated the effect of one of the
strongest El Niños on record in producing record heat in southern Australia. The study uses a novel approach for separating the role of ENSO and anthropogenic climate change within the context of an event attribution study."

"Model simulations indicate that human-induced climate
change was largely to blame for 2015 becoming the hottest
year on record for the planet and regionally for India"

"The unusually severe cold winter days over the eastern US
during 2015 were not symptomatic of human-induced climate
change. In fact, long-term trends show cold outbreaks are less
likely as winters have become warmer and less variable."

"Unusually cold North American temperatures for February
2015 were mostly a symptom of an atmospheric circulation
pattern that was internally generated, rather than being driven
by either sea ice or ocean temperature conditions."
"A region used to high temperatures and dryness was staggered by extraordinary heat and humidity made more likely by climate change."

"Two deadly, unrelated heat waves in India and Pakistan in
2015 were each exacerbated by anthropogenic climate change."

"Human-induced climate change increased the likelihood of the extreme heat that combined with typical El Niño precipitation deficits to produce the drought conditions that dominated Indonesian weather from July through October of 2015."

"Natural variability was the main contributor to conditions
resulting in record low rainfall in October 2015 in Tasmania,
though anthropogenic climate change and El Niño made small
but significant contributions to increasing the likelihood of such
an event."

"Anthropogenic climate change increased the probability that
a short-duration, intense rainfall events and associated flooding, like the one that occurred in May, would occur in parts of southeast China."
"The delayed onset of the wet season over Nigeria during April–May 2015 was not made more likely because of human-caused warming or anomalous sea surface temperatures."

"Human-induced changes in atmospheric chemical and aerosol
composition overall did not influence the severity of extreme
one-day rainfall that occurred over Chennai during December
2015."

"The perception of drab British winters may be challenged as
longer sunny spells , such as the extreme winter sunshine over
the United Kingdom in 2014/15, have become more than 1.5
times more likely under the influence of climate change."

"The extreme intensity of the drought was likely due to two
principal factors: an anthropogenic effect via an unusual early
spring 2015 warming that acted to reduce snow cover and soil
moisture, followed by a naturally occurring persistent upper
ridge that caused heat and low rainfall during May-July 2015."

"Anthropogenic warming contributed to the 2015 Ethiopian and
southern African droughts by increasing local air temperatures
and El Niño sea surface temperatures, causing reduced rainfall
and runoff, and contributing to severe food insecurity."

"Extreme typhoon energy over the region of the western North
Pacific during 2015 was mainly the result of El Niño-related sea
surface warming of the tropical east Pacific, though the effect
of human-induced ocean warming also made such an active
season more likely."

"The 2015 Alaska fire season burned 5.1 million acres, the second-most since records began in 1940. Human-induced climate change may have increased the risk of a fire season of this severity by 34%–60%."

"Human-induced climate change set the stage for conditions
that resulted in the lowest sea-ice extent ever recorded for the
month of March, typically when it reaches its annual maximum
extent in the Arctic."

"Flooding during high tides, on otherwise sunny days in the
coastal Miami region, have increased by more than 500% in
the past two decades. The late September 2015 inundation
event was symptomatic of such a trend in tidal floods that are
becoming commonplace as sea levels rise, in part, due to anthropogenic influences."

"Low snowpack in the Washington Cascades by spring 2015
resulted despite near-normal winter precipitation. Exceedingly
high temperatures, related in part to anthropogenic warming,
reduced the overall regional snowpack"
